p: The epidemiological and evolutionary histories of human and AIVs in North America from 1976â€“2001 are summarized in Figure 1. In humans, seasonal influenza outbreaks exhibit substantial annual variation ( Figure 1A), which is also reflected in shifting dominance of co-circulating subtypes ( Figure 1C). Human influenza viruses exhibit very limited subtype diversity ( Figure 1C), as defined by the number of serologically distinct hemagglutinin (H or HA) glycoprotein types [9], where only H1 and H3 subtypes of influenza A viruses have significantly circulated since 1968 [15]. In addition to this paucity of subtypes, genetic diversity is also limited within H1 ( Figure 1E) and H3 ( Figure 1F) subtypes, as reflected in the slender trunk of the consensus phylogenetic tree ( Figure 1I and 1J).
